subject: Re: QS news update
msgSnippet: I m beginning to think the It Eat rule is actually capturing two instructions. For my own sanity, let me lay out what they seem to be to me. 1. Use #26It at
messageBody:
I'm beginning to think the It Eat rule is actually capturing two
instructions. For my own sanity, let me lay out what they seem to be
to me.

1. "Use #26It at the end of words because what seems like an Eat sound
there is really always an It sound"
This maybe helpful to certain speakers but is clearly not true of all
accents. For these cases I too would screech "vive la difference!".
But the issue seems to be more complex than just this...

--but--

2. "Use #26It to represent the grammatical adjectival ending -y, -ie etc."
This rule is as significant as "use Ing for participle endings". It
makes QS more into morphemic writing which is a feature far more
important than having different accents use the same vowels.
Personally here I would strongly side with Moira.

So maybe the only issue is that the QM oversimplified the rule around
It-Eat.


--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Moira O'Brien" <mj@...> wrote:
>
> I feel I must contribute to this debate in respect of terminal #27EAt or
> #26It.
>
> Kingsley Read was specific in his directions
> - if the syllable is unstressed then use #26 - if it is stressed then
> use #26. This accords with both my speach and most of the English and
> American
> that I hear.
>
> I really cannot understand anyone pronouncing say "family" as
"familee" with
> the stress on the "ee". So I am 100% behind KR's rule of #26 for
unstressed
> terminal "ily" endings and the like.
>
> regards
>
> Moira
>
> On 15/11/2007, Anthony Grahn <othermale@...> wrote:
> >
> > Thanks a million for your review! I've applied the change you
> > suggested and uploaded a new chart.
> >
> > >
> > > And one warning. Some Australians may want to keep terminal
> > > unstressed "Eat" written as #27Eat, rather than #26It.
> > > ...
> > > But some of those spellings are quite idiosyncratic and
> > > would, I think, make Australian QS too difficult to read elsewhere.)
> > > Keep your footnote as it is.
> > >
> >
> > I too am personally annoyed at using a terminal #26It for a sound that
> > to me is obviously "Eat". But Read's rule about this does solve a real
> > issue; namely to make QS more of a morphophonemic writing system. It
> > is the same reason there are rules for omitting vowels when tacking on
> > the letter Zoo for some plurals and Day for past tenses and Ing etc.
> > Maybe the QM rules are in error, thier purpose is certainly never
> > explained. And maybe in some of these cases the burden of non phonemic
> > writing is higher than the morphemic benefit. Personally though I want
> > to clearly analyze and describe these rules before abandoning them.
> >
> > Once the long-over-due morphemic discussion starts I imagine we are
> > going to want more such rules rather than fewer.
> >
> >
>
